title: Three men charged over assault on Labour activist Owen Jones outside pub
text:

Three men have been charged following an assault on Labour activist Owen Jones outside a pub.

The Guardian columnist, 35, had been out celebrating his birthday with friends when he was set upon by a group of men at The Lexington in Islington, London, on August 17.

James Healy, 39, of Portsmouth, Liam Tracey, 34, of Camden, north London, and Charlie Ambrose, 29, of Brighton have been charged by postal requisition with ABH and affray over the incident.

They will appear at Highbury Corner Magistrates' Court on November 6.

The alleged incident happened after Mr Jones and his friends left the pub at about 2am and were saying goodbye to each other.

Mr Jones claimed a group of three or four men 'made a direct beeline for him'.

(Image: BBC)

Writing on Twitter at the time, he said: "Six of us left the pub at 3am and were saying our goodbyes 30 metres away, then a group of 3-4 men left the pub, made a beeline for me, kicked me in the back, threw me on the ground, slamming my head, and kicked me in the skull.

"My friends were punched trying to defend me."

Mr Jones is understood to be 'fine' after the incident but reportedly had a bump on his head.

A photograph also appeared to show scratches to his back.

(Image: Andres Pantoja/SOPA Images/REX)

Met Police detectives previously said they were investigating whether the attack was a hate crime.

Guardian editor Katherine Viner previously condemned the attack.

She said on Saturday evening: "At the Guardian we deplore the outrageous attack on Owen Jones.

"Violent assaults on journalists or activists have no place in a democratic society."
description: The Guardian columnist, 35, had been out celebrating his birthday when he was set upon outside The Lexington in Islington, London
